DOC.HEAD: U.S. Envoy Praises General Assembly
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering hailed the 44th General Assembly Tuesday as ``one of the most constructive, realistic sessions in recent memory'' for its approach to human rights, disarmament and other issues. Pickering, in a reception for reporters, praised the 159-member assembly for ``stepping away from governments which have come to power without the support of the people; respect for human rights; and a willingness to come to grips with such worldwide concerns as drugs, human rights, terrorism and the environment.'' He noted the assembly, which opened in September, had embraced a consensus position on many issues, echoing the cooperative approach to the West initiated by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``Those who defended authoritarian regimes or clung to failed political and economic ways were clearly out of step at this session,'' he said, referring to Cuba, Panama and Nicaragua. ``The 44th General Assembly set the scene for a concrete chemical arms control initiative by President Bush and a positive response from Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze,'' Pickering said. During his speech to the assembly in September, Bush proposed deep cuts in the U.S. and Soviet poison gas stockpiles. Shevardnadze endorsed that idea but counterproposed ending production of chemical weapons as well. U.S. and Soviet negotiators are now reconciling the two approaches. ``The general debate set the tone, with speeches which stressed optimism and pragmatism, downplayed confrontation and welcomed improved East-West relations and the U.N.'s renewed activism in helping to resolve regional conflicts,'' Pickering said. ``This session had its down sides as well,'' he noted. ``Unbalanced resolutions on the Middle East, Central America and SoUthern africa continue to be pursued here,'' he said. Last week, Vice President Dan Quayle visited the United Nations and said the assembly should repeal its 1975 ``Zionism is Racism'' resolution. Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Vladimir Petrovsky said later in the week that his country did not favor a repeal, saying it would provoke a confrontation. Pickering said the United States would push for repeal only when sensed it would win on the issue, saying a defeat would have the effect of giving renewed emphasis to the original resolution. Among the areas of agreement cited by Pickering were consensus resolutions to ban driftnet fishing on the high seas; calling for a free and sovereign Afghanistan; opposing terrorism; denouncing apartheid and calling for a non-racial, democratic society in South Africa. Pickering praised the record number of votes in favor of a comprehensive political settlement to the Cambodian conflict, and record number of votes against the annual Arab attempt to eject Israel from the assembly. Namibia's free and fair elections were a highlight of the year, he said, as were resolutions criticizing human rights violations in Iran, Afghanistan, El Salvador and Chile. Pickering criticized the Palestine Liberation Organization's attempt to upgrade its status from an organization to a non-voting member nation, saying America ``preferred that this issue had never been raised.'' Action on that move was deferred until at least next year after the United States threatened to cut off its $216 million annual dues payment. On Friday, the assembly concludes its annual fall session.
